trans-unit.source: Delegate your domain to Azure DNS | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Delegate your domain to Azure DNS | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Understand how to change domain delegation and use Azure DNS name servers to provide domain hosting.
trans-unit.target: Understand how to change domain delegation and use Azure DNS name servers to provide domain hosting.

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS is a hosting service for DNS domains.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS is a hosting service for DNS domains.

trans-unit.source: In order for DNS queries for a domain to reach Azure DNS, the domain has to be delegated to Azure DNS from the parent domain.
trans-unit.target: In order for DNS queries for a domain to reach Azure DNS, the domain has to be delegated to Azure DNS from the parent domain.

trans-unit.source: This article explains how domain delegation works and how to delegate domains to Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: This article explains how domain delegation works and how to delegate domains to Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: A domain is a unique name in the Domain Name System, for example ‘contoso.com’.
trans-unit.target: A domain is a unique name in the Domain Name System, for example ‘contoso.com’.

trans-unit.source: A domain registrar is a company who can provide Internet domain names.
trans-unit.target: A domain registrar is a company who can provide Internet domain names.

trans-unit.source: They will verify if the Internet domain you want to use is available and allow you to purchase it.
trans-unit.target: They will verify if the Internet domain you want to use is available and allow you to purchase it.

trans-unit.source: Once the domain name is registered, you will be the legal owner for the domain name.
trans-unit.target: Once the domain name is registered, you will be the legal owner for the domain name.

trans-unit.source: If you already have an Internet domain, you will use the current domain registrar to delegate to Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: If you already have an Internet domain, you will use the current domain registrar to delegate to Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: To find out more information on who owns a given domain name, or for information on how to buy a domain, see <linkText>Internet domain management in Azure AD</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To find out more information on who owns a given domain name, or for information on how to buy a domain, see <linkText>Internet domain management in Azure AD</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: A DNS zone is used to host the DNS records for a particular domain.
trans-unit.target: A DNS zone is used to host the DNS records for a particular domain.

trans-unit.source: For example, the domain ‘contoso.com’ may contain a number of DNS records such as ‘mail.contoso.com’ (for a mail server) and ‘www.contoso.com’ (for a website).
trans-unit.target: For example, the domain ‘contoso.com’ may contain a number of DNS records such as ‘mail.contoso.com’ (for a mail server) and ‘www.contoso.com’ (for a website).

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS allows you to host a DNS zone and thereby manage the DNS records for a domain in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS allows you to host a DNS zone and thereby manage the DNS records for a domain in Azure.

trans-unit.source: Keep in mind Azure DNS is not domain registrar.
trans-unit.target: Keep in mind Azure DNS is not domain registrar.

trans-unit.source: The Domain Name System is a hierarchy of domains.
trans-unit.target: The Domain Name System is a hierarchy of domains.

trans-unit.source: The hierarchy starts from the ‘root’ domain, whose name is simply ‘.’.
trans-unit.target: The hierarchy starts from the ‘root’ domain, whose name is simply ‘.’.

trans-unit.source: Below this come top-level domains, such as ‘com’, ‘net’, ‘org’, ‘uk’ or ‘jp’.
trans-unit.target: Below this come top-level domains, such as ‘com’, ‘net’, ‘org’, ‘uk’ or ‘jp’.

trans-unit.source: Below these are second-level domains, such as ‘org.uk’ or ‘co.jp’.
trans-unit.target: Below these are second-level domains, such as ‘org.uk’ or ‘co.jp’.

trans-unit.source: And so on.
trans-unit.target: And so on.

trans-unit.source: The domains in the DNS hierarchy are hosted using separate DNS zones.
trans-unit.target: The domains in the DNS hierarchy are hosted using separate DNS zones.

trans-unit.source: These zones are globally distributed, hosted by DNS name servers around the world.
trans-unit.target: These zones are globally distributed, hosted by DNS name servers around the world.

trans-unit.source: There are two types of DNS servers:
trans-unit.target: There are two types of DNS servers:

trans-unit.source: An authoritative DNS server hosts DNS zones.
trans-unit.target: An authoritative DNS server hosts DNS zones.

trans-unit.source: It answers DNS queries for records in those zones only.
trans-unit.target: It answers DNS queries for records in those zones only.

trans-unit.source: A recursive DNS server does not host DNS zones.
trans-unit.target: A recursive DNS server does not host DNS zones.

trans-unit.source: It answers all DNS queries, by calling authoritative DNS servers to gather the data it needs.
trans-unit.target: It answers all DNS queries, by calling authoritative DNS servers to gather the data it needs.

trans-unit.source: DNS clients in PCs or mobile devices typically call a recursive DNS server to perform any DNS queries the client applications need.
trans-unit.target: DNS clients in PCs or mobile devices typically call a recursive DNS server to perform any DNS queries the client applications need.

trans-unit.source: When a recursive DNS server receives a query for a DNS record such as ‘www.contoso.com’, it first needs to find the name server hosting the zone for the ‘contoso.com’ domain.
trans-unit.target: When a recursive DNS server receives a query for a DNS record such as ‘www.contoso.com’, it first needs to find the name server hosting the zone for the ‘contoso.com’ domain.

trans-unit.source: To do this, it starts at the root name servers, and from there finds the name servers hosting the ‘com’ zone.
trans-unit.target: To do this, it starts at the root name servers, and from there finds the name servers hosting the ‘com’ zone.

trans-unit.source: It then queries the ‘com’ name servers to find the name servers hosting the ‘contoso.com’ zone.
trans-unit.target: It then queries the ‘com’ name servers to find the name servers hosting the ‘contoso.com’ zone.

trans-unit.source: Finally, it is able to query these name servers for ‘www.contoso.com’.
trans-unit.target: Finally, it is able to query these name servers for ‘www.contoso.com’.

trans-unit.source: This is called resolving the DNS name (strictly, DNS resolution includes additional steps such as following CNAMEs, but that’s not important to understanding how DNS delegation works.)
trans-unit.target: This is called resolving the DNS name (strictly, DNS resolution includes additional steps such as following CNAMEs, but that’s not important to understanding how DNS delegation works.)

trans-unit.source: How does a parent zone ‘point’ to the name servers for a child zone?
trans-unit.target: How does a parent zone ‘point’ to the name servers for a child zone?

trans-unit.source: It does this using a special type of DNS record, called an NS record (NS stands for ‘name server’).
trans-unit.target: It does this using a special type of DNS record, called an NS record (NS stands for ‘name server’).

trans-unit.source: For example, the root zone contains NS records for ‘com’, showing the name servers for the ‘com’ zone.
trans-unit.target: For example, the root zone contains NS records for ‘com’, showing the name servers for the ‘com’ zone.

trans-unit.source: In turn, the ‘com’ zone contains NS records for ‘contoso.com’, showing the name servers for the ‘contoso.com’ zone.
trans-unit.target: In turn, the ‘com’ zone contains NS records for ‘contoso.com’, showing the name servers for the ‘contoso.com’ zone.

trans-unit.source: Setting up the NS records for a child zone in a parent zone is called delegating the domain.
trans-unit.target: Setting up the NS records for a child zone in a parent zone is called delegating the domain.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Dns-nameserver</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Dns-nameserver</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Each delegation actually has two copies of the NS records—one in the parent zone pointing to the child, and another in the child zone itself.
trans-unit.target: Each delegation actually has two copies of the NS records—one in the parent zone pointing to the child, and another in the child zone itself.

trans-unit.source: The ‘contoso.com’ zone contains the NS records for ‘contoso.com’ (in addition to the NS records in ‘com’).
trans-unit.target: The ‘contoso.com’ zone contains the NS records for ‘contoso.com’ (in addition to the NS records in ‘com’).

trans-unit.source: These are called authoritative NS records, and they sit at the apex of the child zone.
trans-unit.target: These are called authoritative NS records, and they sit at the apex of the child zone.

trans-unit.source: Once you create your DNS zone in Azure DNS, you need to set up NS records in the parent zone to make Azure DNS the authoritative source for name resolution for your zone.
trans-unit.target: Once you create your DNS zone in Azure DNS, you need to set up NS records in the parent zone to make Azure DNS the authoritative source for name resolution for your zone.

trans-unit.source: For domains purchased from a registrar, your registrar will offer the option to set up these NS records.
trans-unit.target: For domains purchased from a registrar, your registrar will offer the option to set up these NS records.

trans-unit.source: You do not have to own a domain in order to create a DNS zone with that domain name in Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: You do not have to own a domain in order to create a DNS zone with that domain name in Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: However, you do need to own the domain to set up the delegation to Azure DNS with the registrar.
trans-unit.target: However, you do need to own the domain to set up the delegation to Azure DNS with the registrar.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose you purchase the domain ‘contoso.com’, and create a zone with the name ‘contoso.com’ in Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose you purchase the domain ‘contoso.com’, and create a zone with the name ‘contoso.com’ in Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: As the owner of the domain, your registrar will offer you the option to configure the name server addresses (that is, the NS records) for your domain.
trans-unit.target: As the owner of the domain, your registrar will offer you the option to configure the name server addresses (that is, the NS records) for your domain.

trans-unit.source: The registrar will store these NS records in the parent domain, in this case ‘.com’.
trans-unit.target: The registrar will store these NS records in the parent domain, in this case ‘.com’.

trans-unit.source: Clients around the world will then be directed to your domain in Azure DNS zone when trying to resolve DNS records in ‘contoso.com’.
trans-unit.target: Clients around the world will then be directed to your domain in Azure DNS zone when trying to resolve DNS records in ‘contoso.com’.

trans-unit.source: To set up the delegation, you need to know the name server names for your zone.
trans-unit.target: To set up the delegation, you need to know the name server names for your zone.

trans-unit.source: Azure DNS allocates name servers from a pool each time a zone is created, and stores these in the authoritative NS records which are automatically created within your zone.
trans-unit.target: Azure DNS allocates name servers from a pool each time a zone is created, and stores these in the authoritative NS records which are automatically created within your zone.

trans-unit.source: So, to see the name server names, you simply need to retrieve these records.
trans-unit.target: So, to see the name server names, you simply need to retrieve these records.

trans-unit.source: Using Azure PowerShell, the authoritative NS records can be retrieved as follows (the record name “@” is used to refer to records at the apex of the zone).
trans-unit.target: Using Azure PowerShell, the authoritative NS records can be retrieved as follows (the record name “@” is used to refer to records at the apex of the zone).

trans-unit.source: In this example, the zone ‘contoso.com’ has been assigned name servers ‘ns1-04.azure-dns.com’, ‘ns2-04.azure-dns.net’, ‘ns3-04.azure-dns.org’, and ‘ns4-04.azure-dns.info’.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the zone ‘contoso.com’ has been assigned name servers ‘ns1-04.azure-dns.com’, ‘ns2-04.azure-dns.net’, ‘ns3-04.azure-dns.org’, and ‘ns4-04.azure-dns.info’.

trans-unit.source: Each registrar has their own DNS management tools to change the name server records for a domain.
trans-unit.target: Each registrar has their own DNS management tools to change the name server records for a domain.

trans-unit.source: In the registrar’s DNS management page, edit the NS records and replace the NS records with the ones Azure DNS created.
trans-unit.target: In the registrar’s DNS management page, edit the NS records and replace the NS records with the ones Azure DNS created.

trans-unit.source: Having completed the delegation, you can verify that name resolution is working by using a tool such as ‘nslookup’ to query the SOA record for your zone (which is also automatically created when the zone is created).
trans-unit.target: Having completed the delegation, you can verify that name resolution is working by using a tool such as ‘nslookup’ to query the SOA record for your zone (which is also automatically created when the zone is created).

trans-unit.source: Note that you do not have to specify the Azure DNS name servers, since the normal DNS resolution process will find the name servers automatically if the delegation has been set up correctly.
trans-unit.target: Note that you do not have to specify the Azure DNS name servers, since the normal DNS resolution process will find the name servers automatically if the delegation has been set up correctly.

trans-unit.source: Having set up and delegated ‘contoso.com’ in Azure DNS, suppose you would like to set up a separate child zone, ‘partners.contoso.com’.
trans-unit.target: Having set up and delegated ‘contoso.com’ in Azure DNS, suppose you would like to set up a separate child zone, ‘partners.contoso.com’.

trans-unit.source: This follows a similar process to a normal delegation:
trans-unit.target: This follows a similar process to a normal delegation:

trans-unit.source: Create the child zone ‘partners.contoso.com’ in Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: Create the child zone ‘partners.contoso.com’ in Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: Look up the authoritative NS records in the child zone to obtain the name servers hosting the child zone in Azure DNS.
trans-unit.target: Look up the authoritative NS records in the child zone to obtain the name servers hosting the child zone in Azure DNS.

trans-unit.source: Delegate the child zone by configuring NS records in the parent zone pointing to the child zone.
trans-unit.target: Delegate the child zone by configuring NS records in the parent zone pointing to the child zone.

trans-unit.source: The only difference is that in step 3 the NS records must be created in the parent zone ‘contoso.com’ in Azure DNS, rather than being set up via a domain registrar.
trans-unit.target: The only difference is that in step 3 the NS records must be created in the parent zone ‘contoso.com’ in Azure DNS, rather than being set up via a domain registrar.

trans-unit.source: The following PowerShell example demonstrates.
trans-unit.target: The following PowerShell example demonstrates.

trans-unit.source: First, we create the parent and child zones—these can be in same resource group or different resource groups.
trans-unit.target: First, we create the parent and child zones—these can be in same resource group or different resource groups.

trans-unit.source: Next, we retrieve the authoritative NS records from child zone as shown in the next example.
trans-unit.target: Next, we retrieve the authoritative NS records from child zone as shown in the next example.

trans-unit.source: Finally, we create corresponding NS record set in the parent zone to complete the delegation (note that the record set name in the parent zone matches the child zone name, in this case "partners").
trans-unit.target: Finally, we create corresponding NS record set in the parent zone to complete the delegation (note that the record set name in the parent zone matches the child zone name, in this case "partners").

trans-unit.source: As when delegating using a registrar, we can verify that everything is set up correctly by looking up the SOA record of the child zone.
trans-unit.target: As when delegating using a registrar, we can verify that everything is set up correctly by looking up the SOA record of the child zone.
